segments.text: This is an interview with Gabor Nagy by Catherine Mays on November 24, 1990, at his home concerning the Hungarian Revolution of 1956.
In the interest of accumulating knowledge, I am asking you to donate this tape to me or to the Texas A&M Oral History Collection in the University Archives.
Is that all right with you?
Yes, it is.
All right, let's begin with where were you born and when?
I was born in Hungary on the 5th of June, 1941.
My father was a tool and die maker who worked in the same factory ever since he was 12 years old and my mother was a seamstress who was working out of her home to make some extra money.
So what was life growing up in Hungary?
Growing up was it was a very hard life.
My father
And my parents never owed anything, you know, and everything was... Everything we had, they had to work real hard for.
They didn't have any personal possession.
They could never own a house or...
The only thing my father had, the best of his possession was a bicycle.
I mean really he didn't have anything.
Bicycle he had.
He had the bicycle that he used to go to work on and my mother had a sewing machine.
And the apartment where we worked was affiliated to us by the
the factory where my father was working.
In other words, they took so much of your wages off, and then they provided the rental was taken out of the wages, the medical insurance, the fees for that was taken out of his wages.
And by the time he brought the money home, it was hardly enough to make it from one paycheck to the next.
So it was a hard life.
So what were the effects when Khrushchev came in and he started announcing his destalinization policies?
Were you all aware of these policies?

I faintly remember these things because I was still a youngster and it was in the earlier days and I was only about, I would say, eight to ten years old, just barely, you know, starting my years as a student, you know.
a school-aged child, but I heard my father mentioning certain things about it, you know.
They didn't like the way Stalin was doing.
He forced his ideals on everybody and killed a lot of people.
I think Stalin was much worse

in his own ways than Hitler ever was because everything that Hitler did came onto the surface, you know, all the stuff that Stalin did was just, you know, buried away and it was just, you know, it was pretty bad and we didn't feel too
We felt pretty good that de-Stalinization was going to start and we were going to bury it away with his death in 1953, but communism didn't change that much.
People were still starving, people were still overworked, they didn't get enough wages for their work.
It was just another phase of communism as far as, you know, Hungary was concerned.
So you'd say you wanted complete freedom from communism?
Yes, yes, we did want to complete freedom from it, and de-Stalinization probably was a step toward total freedom, but it was, you know, we had a whole long ways to go.
And how did the other countries, Poland, Austria, and Yugoslavia, how did those countries who had somewhat more freedom make the people of Hungary feel?
Well, those people, you know, we were all in the same kind of regime.
We were all under communistic rule, you know.
But those nations, you know, they felt the pain that Hungary felt, and we were all trying to, you know, I guess...

Like a big family, you know, we all comforted one another and we were all looking for a way out of it and that's what the Hungarian Revolution of 1956 started, you know, and everybody benefited from it.
Do you feel it began with the students or with all of the people of Hungary?
I think that at the beginning the students really kindled the flame to get something started, especially the students of Poland,
who had a big demonstration on the 23rd of October, 1956, that really started the youth of the Hungarian universities on the same track.
And they also started a big uprising the following day.
And then all this, the news got around throughout the nation, and the workers
When my father worked, for instance, he was the big organizer to get the strike started, which backed up the students in their demands.
What changes did the students and the people of Hungary want to see in 1956?
Well, the students had a proclamation a couple days after the revolution started.
I think it was on the second or the third day
they had a 12-point demand that they put in front of the... that the people were demanding, you know.
And one of the demands were freedom of the press, freedom of religion, freedom of speech.
And they just wanted a total freedom away from all the... You know, they didn't want the KBG to go...
go in the middle of the night and arresting people.
They just wanted a total freedom of all of that.
What kind of leader did you feel in the students' village that Imre Nagy was going to be for your country?
Well, Imre Nagy, he was a good person who was in parliament previous to the 1956

revolution and he was one of the persons who wanted the total freedom from communism and his government he was you know after the revolution started which was a very short lived because it ended in a couple of weeks time but he he
He wanted what the student wanted, and then the total abolishment of communism and all the points that the students put forth, he acknowledged them.

So when he was put in as premier of Hungary, how did the people feel when Nagy was... Oh, they were overwhelmed, and everybody thought that the revolution's going to survive, and they started to open up all the prisons, so the prisoners, political prisoners, went free, and they really looked forward to...
to a new way of life.
So when the Soviets began to intervene, and they started coming in, what were your first memories?
Well, it was pretty bad.
See, I lived in Debrecen at the time, which was the eastern part of Hungary, and that was really close to the Russian border, about, I would say, about 10, 15 miles, that's all.
And it was really bad because...
One of the points of the student proclamation was to break away from the

break away from the Warsaw Pact, which stated that the Soviet troops were allowed to stay in Hungary, you know, and the student says, we don't want the Warsaw Pact, we want to break away from it, we want the Russians out of the
country, you know, out of Hungary.
And when I saw the Russians coming back in, we knew that there was something, some trouble.
Now, what had happened is that while Imre Nagy was the premier, another government was formed secretly behind him who asked the Russians help.

that's how come the Russians the tanks started coming in you know and that's that's that was the turning point when the Hungarian Revolution you know when the Soviets intervened that's when the Soviets intervened and that was like on a Sunday of November 4th and Monday November 5th when when the Russian tanks were just coming back in you know and then they broke down the revolution
When Nagy asked the revolutionaries, he's like, you know, stop, you know, stop fighting.
Did you feel like he was just being influenced by the Russians by, you know, saying, asking, just wanting the revolution to be stopped?
Well, Imre Nagy, at the beginning, he had to kind of...

pleased both parties at the beginning because he wanted to have the wanted to please the existing government and on the other hand he was he was really in favor of the revolution and in the beginning he was kinda was telling everybody actually to stop fighting is not a bad thing to ask you know you can stop fighting and you can resolve your problems or resolve your requests as a you know
at a diplomatic way, you know, and so stop fighting wasn't a bad request, you know, and you know we would all, you know, wanted to do that.
So you did want to stop fighting?
We did want to stop the fight and then resolve it legally.
And they did stop fighting.
But when the Russian tanks came back in, that's when things were kind of lost.
You couldn't fight against the tanks and everything.
So that kind of put an end to it.
What were some of your memories?
Do you have memories of the... Oh yes, there's a...
This section really could go on for hours and hours, because I can expand on the revolution, you know, as little as it short-lived it was, but there was a lot of things happened over there, really.
If you want me to expand on certain parts of it, maybe we can do that.
You want me to do that now, or is it... No, go ahead.
Expand on some of the memories you have of the days of the revolution.
The earlier days of the revolution was very trying because there was a lot of street fighting, and as I earlier said, my father was...
working in this, uh, locomotive factory as a tool and die maker.
And he was the person who organized one of the major strikes in Davidson, uh, because this factory employed about 10,000 people and they were all, all workers.
And my father was working there from, uh, when he was 12 years old until that time.
And, uh, 56, he was, he was about, uh,
40 years old at the time, you know.
Actually he was, yeah, well anyway, and he was like a foreman and he had a lot of influence with the people.
And I remember

He told the people to go on strike and the next couple of days they took my father away in jail and then they held him there until he releases a statement to the press that the people would go back to work, that he would ask the workers to go back to work.

he would not he wouldn't do that so they kept him in jail he was in jail for about a week you know until close to the end of the month in you know until like October 28th or 29th you know of 1956 and then he decided

and when he found that things were starting to deteriorate and everything, he did sign a statement and told the people to go back to work, you know, but it wasn't really a statement that he wanted to really do.
He knew that the revolution was kind of doomed anyway.
This was his way of getting out of prison, you know.
So when they let him out,
That's when my father came home that very night, and we picked up all our belongings.
I have a sister who is a year younger than I am.
He also lives in Haltom City, and he works with General Dynamics now.
But just the four of us with all the money that my mother and father, all their savings, and just a coat on our backs and a suitcase, so we took off.
And then we came out from Debrecet,
from Debra's end to the iron curtain.
The iron curtain was nothing more than a fence, an electrified fence of about six foot high that
It was called the Iron Curtain, you know, and that was from the western.
That was about three to four hundred miles long along the western part of Hungary.
Mostly, the most fortified area was around Austria.
Austria and actually the border between Hungary and Austria is not very large but the border was going around more on the western part of it.
But anyway, so we took a train from Debrecen to Austrian border which is about I would say about 300 miles and

being my father a locomotive factory worker he was able to start a freedom train from Debrecen all the way to through Budapest to western part of Hungary and this train started and everybody got loaded up in Debrecen the whole train about 15
cars, you know, and then we all went and they didn't stop until it got to the other side.
And about 50 miles from the western border we heard the news that there are some Russians at Sopron, which is the very final city, you know, before Austria.
that there were people over there waiting for the train to come through so they can arrest everybody.
So what happened at this point, the train stopped, and everybody got out, and we took the rest of the way, the last good 50 miles.
Well, actually, I don't remember exactly how much it was, but we walked all night.
I mean, all night long through...
fields and no streets.
I mean, it was pitch dark.
It wasn't a night where there was a full moon.
I mean, I was just petrified because one time I lost my, I lost contact.
I hold my sister's hand, but my sister wasn't holding my father's hand.
So kind of, but anyway, I was already 15 years old, so I wasn't really that scared, but my sister was started to cry.
She was 14, but she cried.
But anyway, and then we came to this, we had to stop.
During the day, we hid in fields of hay, you know, and we were waiting for the night to come, and that evening, we were hiding a whole day in the fields, and we didn't dare go out, you know.
We hardly ate anything, too, I remember that.

and at night we went to this village and we knocked on people's door trying to ask them directions how to get to uh how to get over to Austria you know and finally this person says oh I'll I'll get you over there I know exactly the way how to go and everything and my mother gave all the all the money that we had because we didn't have any use for it in Austria and uh he
He got lost and we got caught.
I mean, we were caught, you know.
And when we were walking over there, all of a sudden a flashlight shines into my father's face and asked him where they were going, you know.
So my father didn't answer.
He said, if you don't know where you're going, you know,

you don't need to ask that question you know where we're going so then we got arrested you see and then we got to this place where they were about it was a border patrol station and there were about 20 30 people already arrested that night over there we were the only people as a as a as a family you know everybody was kind of like single you know and uh it was very sad my mother was crying and everything and later on uh
The place, gunshots were fired, you know, and we thought that perhaps the place was attacked by freedom fighters, so we're going to be all freed again.
But it wasn't the case.
The lieutenant who was the controlling person of the border, he came in drunk and he was shooting his gun in the dark, you know.

So at that time, my mother went in and took a bottle of... We got a little whiskey, a couple of bottles of whiskey, because my godfather had a restaurant, and he had some whiskey and some brandy hidden away, you know, because they took his...
restaurant away, you know, it was more like a pub, you know.

and uh but he had some hidden whiskey and gave us a couple of bottles and my mother gave one of the bottles to the guy who was drunk and in return he he would ask us he asked if he if he would let us go you know and he did you know and he let us go and he even gave a soldier to to show us through the border you know because we were the only family you know everybody was single so
He probably figured, well, you know, he's got reasons that he...

If he would have gotten sent back to Debrecen, my father would have probably gotten a bad sentence or either life or he was... A lot of people were sentenced to life imprisonment or sent to Siberia, you know, or executed.
This we found out after he got settled in America, you know.
But anyway, it's...
That's how we got across and we got to Austria.
There are a lot of things happened in Austria.
And if you want me to expand on that, I can.
I was going to ask you, this time during the revolution, did you feel that other countries should come to your aid?
Or did you all think they were going to come to your aid?
Well, during the course of the revolution,
Radio Free Europe had mentioned and pleaded several times with the United Nations and specifically to Hungary, to the United States, to interfere and to liberate the Hungarian people.
And it was a big, big disappointment that nobody came to the help of the Hungarian people.
But later on, you know, the people realized that really, if they would have interfered with Hungary, it would have been interference with the whole Soviet Union.
So it would have been a little bit bigger deal than just taking care of the Hungarian people.
I'm sure that...
the Russians would have, you know, really gotten, you know, on the side of the Hungarians and it would have, could have, you know, start the Third World War.
So with this in view, you know, it probably was better that the United Nations didn't come, you know, because it could have started the Third World War.
But it was a big disappointment because, you know, we lost our freedom.
We had it for two weeks and that was it.
So you were able to listen to Radio Free Europe?
You did have access to it?
Radio Free, yes.
We had access to Radio Free Europe in those two weeks because they were constantly jamming the signal and not much of the stuff was coming through.
But during the course of the revolution, you know, it was pretty clear, yes.
So you were able to get to the United States.
You can go ahead and expand.
Yes.
OK, well, just shortly, I don't want to take up too much time.
But in Austria, when we came to Austria, the Austrian people were so good to help to pave the way of these people who came from Hungary.
During the course of the revolution, about 150,000 people died.
because of the atrocities and the killings of the Russians and the communist people.
The AVO, they called them, is the Hungarian secret police who really went after these people and they killed them, you know, and tortured them and everything.
And another 150,000

fled the country and they said afterwards that another 100,000 was deported and killed after, you know, they got after the people who were part, who took part in the revolution and they caught all of those people.
So more than a quarter million people
were either killed, displaced or sent to prison because of this revolution.
We were fortunate enough to leave the country and come to the United States.
We had trying times in Austria because everything was so disorganized.
Austrian people did the best they could, you know.
I remember we walked the streets for two, three days because the government was so disorganized.
This thing happened so suddenly
And with such a massive, you know, the people were just coming so fast all through Austria, you know, that they weren't ready for it.
So the Austrian government was dependent on the people to take care of the immediate needs of the Hungarians.
So we were
we were called in from the streets, when we were walking down the streets, people opened their doors and said, come on in, we'll give you breakfast, or come on in, we'll give you lunch, you know.

This was for a couple of days until the government did come and got more organized and put us on buses and we went to a place in the mountains where they had a big hotel and they put us up over there.
What were some of the feelings toward the U.S.?
I always, I don't know why, but I always had a sixth sense about, you know, that I'm going to go to the United States.
When I was a little child, I always yearned to come, and I probably would have come even if my parents would have stayed over there.
The people were very open-minded and looked very favorable upon, you know, the United States.
And even though we were fed all this, you know,
brainwashing about how the differences between colored people and white people, you know, were, it was all went,
into smoke because, you know, this wasn't really what was happening.

It was just, you know, when I first saw a first colored person in Austria, he was a doctor, and he's the one who examined me because everybody who, you know, came had to go through a thorough examination, and it was just wonderful.
He was a doctor, and I, you know,
We thought under Stalinism that there's a great depression of the colored people, and between the coloreds and the white, they had racial differences.
In the United States?
Yes, in the United States.
And I didn't think that was true.
There might be some differences, but not as deep as what they were saying.
So what do you feel, what were some of the things that happened when you first got to the United States?
Well, after Austria, we were still in Austria from the 3rd of November until January of 1957, which was January 7th or 8th.
is when we finally got out of the... we were living in an Austrian hotel for about a month and a half and they were saying that somebody will come from the Hungarian consulate and will
give us visas to the United States.

At this time, the United States had opened up the quota to let a certain amount of Hungarian refugees in due to the revolution, and they let 20,000 people in Hungary, from Hungary to the United States, and we were trying to be one of the 20,000 and
My family felt the need to leave the camp and go to Vienna on our own so we can surely make the quota because we were kind of close already.
You know, everybody was filling in.
We got some free train passes from the mountains.
It was about 90 miles or 100 miles from the mountains.
We had bus passes, we had train passes, and so we got to Vienna.
We were looking for the consulate.
I spoke a little German, so we were able to manage our way, but somehow...
The police caught us because we were wandering up and down the streets and we were kind of curious looking bunch.
So they arrested us because they really didn't arrest us, but we didn't know where to sleep.
So they took us in jail because that's why they had the most room.
So when we went over there, but the people in the jail did not know
that we weren't prisoners, you know, so they treated us like prisoners for about a day or so.
We had to go to bed early and get up real early also, and then we were given just the prison food, and we had to go do the chores.
We had to get up and wash the foot.
And after that,
I told them, we're not prisoners.
We're here to go to the United States.
We need to go to the consulate.
And they let us go, you know.
And I remember this was during the New Years of 1956.
